Hello,

My name is Darin and I am the President of Team Performance Products. Designing and producing a prototype of these golf clubs was a lifelong dream of mine. With your help we can bring it to market. The designs are complete and the manufacturers are ready to go, so we need to raise a minimum of $50,000 to market the clubs through a national media buy. So, we need you to help our dream become a reality!  As you saw from our video, we are bringing two clubs to market - a driver and putter.
DRIVER

Our driver head is constructed from nothing but the finest Titanium Alloy available. Its 15.3.3.3 variable thickness face allows you maximum trampoline effect to maximize your distance. Even with its spring-like effect, you will have the kind of power and control all golfers long for. The bulge and roll, along with the contour of the club face, will help you keep your fades from fading, and your hooks from hooking, allowing you to hit more shots from the fairway! This monster 460cc club face has a huge sweet spot that allows it to be one of the most forgiving drivers you will ever swing!

Our goal, when designing this driver head, was to allow all golfers - pros and amateurs alike - to hit the ball farther and with more power while not sacrificing fairways hit. Testing by Golf Laboratories, Inc. shows the Team Performance driver outdistancing the top 3 name brand manufacturers proving this driver is a game changer off the tee. This driver head is sure to improve your power, distance and control!
PUTTER

The Team Performance Putter is constructed of high density aluminum alloy to provide you with the best feel possible when the ball impacts the club face. The symmetrical design has perfect weight distribution throughout the putter head. This feature combined with a center cut shaft club face design gives you perfect balance so you have a flawless putter stroke. Its big T-Line is designed to square up the club at impact so you have a better chance of hitting a straighter and accurate putt. Its beautiful modern design will help distinguish it as one of the premier putters on the market today.

Our putter head is finished with a high gloss midnight black paint. However, as a special way of saying thank you to our Indiegogo backers, we have asked the manufacturer to produce a special run of 200 snow white Limited Edition putter heads. The first 200 lucky backers that pledge $125 or more will receive one of these specialty putters!
SHAFTS

Loomis high performance golf shafts by Meyer Performance Composites, LLC are manufactured using some of the highest modulus materials available. The unique and proprietary manufacturing process allows Loomis to produce some of the densest laminates in the golf shaft industry. This process is what gives Loomis golf shafts the superior feel and performance that many professionals rely on.
The picture above reflects some of the colleges that are available on our shafts. All shafts are Licensed and approved by the NCAA. Here are some additional teams that are now available:
DRIVER TESTING

Golf Laboratories is the premier independent testing facility serving the golf industry. The robots built and used by Golf Laboratories have become the standard for machine testing amongst the major equipment manufacturers. For the past 10 years, Golf Laboratories, Inc. has established proven testing methods to ensure quality results. Through the use of a robotic arm, a direct comparison of multiple golf drivers can be made.
The chart below outlines the results of robotic arm testing on the Team Performance Driver 9.5 and 10.5, Taylor Made r7, Callaway FT-5, and Nike SQ.

Now, a lot of times when you put a logo on a product, people naturally assume it's a novelty item. But, at Team Performance Products, our priority will always be quality and performance first, with the added appeal of your favorite college team proudly displayed on your Loomis high performance shaft. With the Team Performance Product line, we want to make sure that our logo products not only look great, but perform to the highest standards!

Indiegogo supporters, by backing our project, you will not only feel good about helping us bring our company to life, but you will also have one of the best golf products in the industry!  THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!

Who Is Aysia

Aysia is a 12 year-old girl who sustained a major hypoxic ischemic injury to the brain at birth. She is diagnosed with profound spastic quadriparetic cerebral palsy, which results in significant muscle tone impairment. Aysia is an exceptional person with an enormous, good-natured spirit. She is a highly social and joyful young lady who enjoys listening to music and interacting with her family and friends. Her smile is radiant and infectious. Highly motivated, her potential to succeed is unlimited.

Challenges of Not Having a Wheelchair Van
Although Aysia has made
some progress walking by taking steps with complete assistance, her quality of
life is threatened by unreliable transportation. As she continues to grow
physically, so do the challenges that we (mom and dad) are faced with. Her body
has become more difficult to lift and transfer, and her spasticity is harder to
overcome. She is at high risk for falls and fractures and requires the use of a
wheelchair for travel.
The functional transfers
that we perform regularly have become more complicated, increasing the risk of
injury to Aysia and her caregivers. Though the wheelchair affords her some
mobility, traveling via vehicle requires additional equipment. She needs a
wheelchair-adaptive van with a lift to carry her to and from doctor
appointments and community events, such as church and school. Without adaptive
equipment to ease the transfers, there’s always the chance of bodily injury. Because
of the high probability of this risk, Aysia is unable to attend private physical,
occupational and speech therapy.
Benefits
of Having a Wheelchair Van
This specialized
vehicle would be a tremendous help in taking Aysia to family gatherings and
continuous occupational, physical and speech therapy appointments. All of these
activities work collaboratively to allow Aysia to acquire new skills,
participate in community events, and improve her well-being. Limiting physical
strain during functional transfers will not only relieve us, but also improve
Aysia’s quality of life.
The
Next Step
As Aysia’s parents, we will
do everything possible to improve her physical and emotional well-being. With
your help, we can raise the funding needed to get her a well-deserved

wheelchair van. So, let’s make it happen!

Your
assistance would be greatly appreciated! Thank you for reading!
If We Don’t Reach
Our Goal
We will put the money in For the Life and Love of Aysia’s
savings until we reach our goal. One small donation will have life changing impact!
The Impact
Aysia has lots of doctors’ appointments and loves being out
in the community. Your gift would make it much easier for her to travel to and
from these activities. She would be able to resume therapy sessions and enjoy
her surroundings. Your contribution will help mom, dad, and Aysia’s caregivers,

too. It makes a difference!

 You can also contribute by check. Go to any

Wells Fargo Bank - ""Aysia Clements/ For the Life and Love of Aysia""

","Team Heart, a 501 c 3 organization based in Boston and operating in Rwanda, includes volunteer physicians, nurses, highly skilled critical technicians and non clinical volunteers dedicated to providing life-saving cardiac surgeries in Rwanda. Our volunteers come from 10 states and 15 medical centers across the U.S. During our first trip to Rwanda, Team Heart volunteers encountered several children and adolescents dying from rheumatic heart disease, a preventable condition.
To date, Team Heart has organized echocardiagram screening for nearly 4000 people, provided more than 100 life-saving surgeries, and continues to perform 1 out of 4 heart surgeries across Rwanda.
Here is Jean Paul's story, one of our first patients in Rwanda. Thousands more patients are suffering from rheumatic heart disease.

For 8 years, Team Heart has collaborated with dedicated partners and supporters to address this disease burden in Rwanda. Our ultimate goal : to build the first national cardiovascular center of excellence for surgery, prevention, education,training, and patient support. But first, we need to address the critical needs of prevention, awareness and early intervention.

We are committed to restoring the health, dignity and future of communities affected by rheumatic heart disease in Rwanda. Please join our cause by donating any amount, large or small.",1.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Boston, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bridge-the-gap-critical-cardiac-care-in-rwanda/pica

column7:
>Spartan Race For The Children's Hospital.

RAISING MONEY FOR KIDS.

column1: (Tax deductible receipts available).
We'll be brief. Ben Erickson a marketing consultant and graphic designer with TMS has enrolled to run the Spartan Beast Race in an attempt to raise fund for the BC Children's Hospital.
At first we attempted to talk him out of it, but when he explained WHY, we knew we had to back him. Here is what Ben had this to say:

""Let's face it. There is no one more helpless than a child. Especially a sick one. 3 years ago my wife and I were blessed with a healthy son, but not everyone we know has been so fortunate. The first time our wee little boy got sick, we began to understand just a bit of what some parents deal with daily.
Parents know that there is nothing worse than a sick child. So small and helpless, sad, not understanding and just wanting their parents comfort.
Imagine dealing with that daily.
Worse, imagine knowing your child's days are numbered and will be but brief.
That is why I - a 32 year old who has spent the last 10 years behind a desk - am training to take on the 21km, 26 obstacle Spartan Beast Race.
Because I believe no one is too small, too old, too incapable to improve the world for others. Because I want to DO SOMETHING.""
Transition Marketing is backing our would-be athlete with everything we have. Check it out:

Who Is BC Children's Hospital?

BC Children's Hospital is the top medical facility for children in BC. The BCCH provides care for children from throughout the province, intervening and providing necessary procedures for countless families each year.
They work all day, every day to save OUR children's lives.
• 67% of patients at BCCH every year are from areas outside of Greater Vancouver.
<li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >52% of the open heart surgeries performed at BCCH last year were performed on children under 1 year old.

column1:
• Last year BCCH provided 8200 surgeries for life threatening issues.
  • BC Children's Hospital received over 196,000 children's vists last year.
More Here

You Make The Difference - #DoSomething.

Even the smallest donation will make a big difference. 100% of the funds raised will go straight to the BC Children's Hospital. Whether it is $5 or $500 it all adds up and it all goes to improving the lives of sick and inured children.
Don't be afraid to donate! Just imagine, every dime raised here will go towards saving lives and providing comfort to those who deserve it most - our children.

column3: >Keep in mind Ben is 32 years old. He was active in High School and for a while after, but has maintained a desk job for the last 12 years. He admits himself that he is not sure how he will finish, but insists HE WILL FINISH.

","Spartan Race For The Children's Hospital. RAISING MONEY FOR KIDS.
(Tax deductible receipts available).
We'll be brief. Ben Erickson a marketing consultant and graphic designer with TMS has enrolled to run the Spartan Beast Race in an attempt to raise fund for the BC Children's Hospital.
At first we attempted to talk him out of it, but when he explained WHY, we knew we had to back him. Here is what Ben had this to say:

Let's face it. There is no one more helpless than a child. Especially a sick one. 3 years ago my wife and I were blessed with a healthy son, but not everyone we know has been so fortunate. The first time our wee little boy got sick, we began to understand just a bit of what some parents deal with daily.
Parents know that there is nothing worse than a sick child. So small and helpless, sad, not understanding and just wanting their parents comfort.
Imagine dealing with that daily.
Worse, imagine knowing your child's days are numbered and will be but brief.
That is why I - a 32 year old who has spent the last 10 years behind a desk - am training to take on the 21km, 26 obstacle Spartan Beast Race.
Because I believe no one is too small, too old, too incapable to improve the world for others. Because I want to DO SOMETHING.""
Transition Marketing is backing our would-be athlete with everything we have. Check it out:

Who Is BC Children's Hospital? BC Children's Hospital is the top medical facility for children in BC. The BCCH provides care for children from throughout the province, intervening and providing necessary procedures for countless families each year.
They work all day, every day to save OUR children's lives.
67% of patients at BCCH every year are from areas outside of Greater Vancouver.
52% of the open heart surgeries performed at BCCH last year were performed on children under 1 year old.
Last year BCCH provided 8200 surgeries for life threatening issues. BC Children's Hospital received over 196,000 children's vists last year.
More Here

You Make The Difference - #DoSomething. Even the smallest donation will make a big difference. 100% of the funds raised will go straight to the BC Children's Hospital. Whether it is $5 or $500 it all adds up and it all goes to improving the lives of sick and inured children.
Don't be afraid to donate! Just imagine, every dime raised here will go towards saving lives and providing comfort to those who deserve it most - our children.
Worried about legitimacy? TMS has a track record of working with non-profits - here are a few:
Relief & Support Services Canada.
Children at Risk - Recycle for Life.
BCCH - ""Worlds Largest Garage Sale"".
The Spartan Race.
The Spartan Race is the nations largest obstacle race. Ben is registered in the Sept 27, Spartan ""Beast"" race at Sun Peaks Resort in Kamloops, BC.
The race is a total of 21 kilometers with 26 obstacles which include:
Jumping over fires.
Climbing 20' ropes.
Running through tires.
Wall climbs.
Crawling through mud.

Keep in mind Ben is 32 years old. He was active in High School and for a while after, but has maintained a desk job for the last 12 years. He admits himself that he is not sure how he will finish, but insists HE WILL FINISH.

Ben, his wife Lauren and their son Miles.Yup, we think he is crazy to, but he's stubborn enough to do it. He has begun training already and has been running 7.25Km offroad three times a week.  Other Ways You Can Help We'll have a page up at Transitionmarketing.ca but TMS is adding the hashtag #DoSomething to the campaign. Follow it on Social Media to keep up to date with Ben's training and of course the outcome of the race.
Twitter: Follow @MarketingTMS https://twitter.com/MarketingTMS
Facebook: www.facebook.com/transitionmarketing
Please donate and share the word. Check out the hashtag on Social Media and pass the word along. Remember - it's all for the kids!

Our Project: A community well

Click on the photo to see a great video telling the story of water.

After years of civil war, Liberians still struggle to gain access to
drinking water, making everyday life extremely difficult. And with the
government low on resources many communities seek to tackle the problem
themselves.The PBS report above briefly explains some of the obstacles
to fresh water encountered by many, and with the current Ebola outbreak
and state of emergency declared in Monrovia, the country's capital,

water has become even more scarce.

To solve this situation, the
community in Barnesville, a short distance from central Monrovia, has
mobilized and is organizing to build a water pump. The building and
maintenance of the pump, done by the people of the community, will
benefit all those living in the area, as there is currently no well. But
in order to realize this essential goal, financial support is needed

for the equipment, transportation and construction of the well.

To
get water, people must walk into neighboring areas. With the
restriction of movement due to the Ebola outbreak there are fewer and
fewer options available. In addition to the distance and scarcity of
water, there are also cases of well poisoning in wells that are not
guarded, making drinking potentially life-threatening. This frustrating
reality makes safe drinking water, which is a basic necessity, very hard
to come by. A water pump owned and looked after by the community will
alleviate the problem and empower the community, allowing us to address
other problems and go on with their lives as healthier and happier

people. For this, we kindly ask for your contribution!


A Personal Story

Omri Preiss, at the time a student living in the Netherlands, traveled to Ghana in 2006 to volunteer in Budubrum Refugee  Camp, home to a community of Liberians who had escaped the Civil Wars of the 1990s. There he met and worked with Emmanuel J. Toe, a teacher at the local primary school, and a Liberian refugee himself. Emmanuel was, and still is, a truly inspiring educator, who encouraged students to see themselves as the future of Liberia, with a responsibility to building a brighter future for their community. His vision, optimism and conviction were truly empowering. Omri and Emmanuel became friends, and stayed in touch in the years that followed. Emmanuel completed a business management diploma in Ghana, returned to Liberia together with many from Buduburam, and made a new home for his family in Barnesville. He continued to teach at the primary school there, while pursuing his own education, and working for his community.

Now, with our connection between Liberia and the Netherlands, we are trying to support Emmanuel's community in their efforts to rebuild their lives and achieve a higher quality of life together. This is a simple personal intitive, there are no big NGOs involved, and contributions you make will go directly to the community, entirely for the purpose of safe cleaning water. Please get in touch with us if you have any questions!   


The Financial Side

The majority of the money will go towards paying for the pump. The
remainder is used for materials and equipment, transportation and
construction. The whole process is overseen by trusted and known
community workers, ensuring that all the money raised is directly and
transparently invested in the project.
The total cost of the project is $1,800. The following is a detailed breakdown of where the money will go:
• The pump head - $800
• 10 bags of cement, $10 each - $100
• Water pump machine to clean the well from dirty water - $100
• 12 covers to be placed in the well, $50 per cover - $600
• Transportation from Monrovia to our community - $75
• Workmanship and construction - $125
The community will use its own resources for the project, and
continue to raise money to ensure the completion of the project.  Money
is an important means to reach many social goals, so any excess money

will be used for equally important purposes if that should be the case!


Contribute and Share!

While there is currently little that we can offer in return for your
generous help, we will be extremely grateful and appreciative of all who
make a contribution for our cause. As you well know, water is vital for
everyone, and you can directly contribute to the well-being of an entire
community of people! This is something that will be felt by everyone in
the community and for large donations we will send a personal card with

pictures of the well once it is finished, as a token of our gratitude.

Your
contributions will be greatly valued, but we understand that not
everyone can contribute. If not, but still want to help us, let others
know of our project and spread the word to individuals and organization
who might be willing to help. In that way, you are also helping us make a

change for the better!

Summary

My mother, Celeste, was diagnosed with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) a year and a half ago. ALS, also called Lou Gehrig's disease, causes the nerve cells in my mother's body to degenerate. This eventually spreads to the neurons in her muscles, causing them to atrophy. She was in a wheel chair just barely a year after being diagnosed. Six months ago, she received a chair she could control with only the movement of her head, which is all that she has left.

Little over a month ago, after surgery to insert a feeding tube, she began to complain of stomach pains and soon after she went into respiratory failure and stopped breathing. Her family, a hardworking husband who supports Celeste's three daughters and young son, has been camped out in the waiting room of the ICU at the hospital. Unable to return to work, Jeff (Celeste's husband) was struggling to support the children even with the help of his mother and Anne, Celeste's best friend. Now that Celeste is stable and living in a rehabilitation center closer to home, the insurance won't cover home health care and Celeste is left in the care of strangers while her family rebuilds. 

Our Story

Celeste moved to Florida in 2009 with her 4 children (Hunter, Mariah, Alexis, and Nikolas) after she divorced. She and Jeff met while she was working as a waitress at Bob Evans' and then at Sonny's. Jeff's father actually introduced them and teased him until he asked her out. He showed up at our door step one day, suitcases in hand, and he's been there ever since. They love each other so much. When she was originally diagnosed, she told him to leave her because she had gone through this with her own mother and knew what would happen. She didn't want this for him, or for us, but he stayed. My mother is the greatest person I have ever known and she's been through so much. Jeff took responsibility of us kids and, with some help, has been getting us through all of this. 

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

We want to bring Celeste home, but to do that we need the funds to pay a nurse's salary. The funds would cover at least an 8 hour shift 5 days a week, allowing Jeff time to return from work or Alexis--Celeste's daughter--to get home from school. While we can't offer anything in return, we would greatly appreciate any help. Please help us bring Celeste home.  

The Impact

There is no cure for ALS, currently. But you can help Celeste return home and finish her time comfortably with her family. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, please share our story and do the #ALSicebucketchallenge. Any help is appreciated.

**Update**

I can't emphasize enough that every financial contribution, whether big or small, is greatly appreciated. I'd like to request that we each contribute the price of one cup of coffee/tea to this campaign today. In North America, that's $2-$5. It seems like so little, and yet that's more than most of our clients take home in 1 day. Together, this seemingly small contribution will have a big impact. Will you join me?
**End of Update**
Hope worldwide Kenya is a non-governmental organization registered in 1999.  We would like to give you a brief primer on what we do, why we do it, and how you can help.
What We Do

Our work focuses on hard-to-reach and most-at-risk populations, orphaned and vulnerable children, youth and poor communities to improve their quality of life through responsive and innovative health programming, service delivery and capacity building in Kenya and Eastern Africa.  Through key partnerships with our local, national and international networks, we are continuously striving to improve the quality of our services and expand the range of our interventions.  We run a health clinic in Mukuru, an urban slum in Nairobi that served 1,200 slum residents free of charge in 2012. The majority of our clients come to the clinic requesting family planning services and STI (sexually transmitted infection) screening and treatment. Our medical professionals also treat a wide variety of other ailments and make referrals when more specialized medical services are required.

We are dependent on donations in order to operate the health clinic.  Although we get some donations of medication from local pharmaceutical companies, most of the donated medications are given when they are close to expiration.  As a result, a large proportion of the donated medications need to be thrown away.  Our stock of medication is running low.  We are requesting your assistance in meeting our objective of continuing to provide free health care and medications to our clients who desperately need our services.
Why We Do It

Our services are greatly needed as we serve the most vulnerable at our clinic.  The unemployment rate in Kenya increased to 40% in 2011 from 12.7% in 2006. The majority of our clients have no reliable source of income and/or cannot afford to pay for needed medications themselves. Also, a sales tax increase was implemented nationwide in September that has further financially strained our clients.
How You Can Help

We are seeking $5,000 in funding, which would cover the cost of stocking our health clinic with medications for 1 year.  Your contribution towards our goal is greatly needed and appreciated.  If we do not meet our fundraising goal, all funds received will still go towards stocking our health clinic for as long as possible.
Other Ways You Can Help
Please help us get the word out about this campaign.  Use Indiegogo share tools, social media and word-of-mouth to tell as many people as possible about this need.  Thank you so much.
Please refer to the Hope worldwide Kenya website for further information about our work:
http://www.hopewwkenya.org/

Beneufit's Parkinson’s Disease Pilot Study results are in.

Beneufit's Parkinson’s Disease Pilot Study demonstrates its product, pdFIT,™ increases manual dexterity and fitness capacity in subjects with Parkinson’s disease.

During the 12-week study period subjects increased their fitness capacity as measured by Beneufit’s fitFactor™ score by 38% and manual dexterity as measured by their circleTap™ score by 25%.

Click here to access the full report.



Exercise As Medicine
We all know exercise is good for you. Anyone who's been diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, had a stroke, heart attack, traumatic brain injury or heart attack knows that exercise is a major part of the healing process.

Our Story
Three years ago Beneufit Co-Founder and CEO Jeff Broderick had the pleasure of meeting Nan Little while fly-fishing at Silver Creek, Idaho. Nan was riding her road bike on the deck of the visitors center and she mentioned following a certain protocol had dramatically reduced her Parkinson's disease symptoms. However,Nan was frustrated because there was no way to quantify her performance or track what she was doing over time. Being a technologist and a cyclist himself, Jeff was inspired to take Nan's experience and turn it into a product.

In October, three years to the day after their initial encounter Jeff returned to Silver Creek to meet Nan and present her with the product that she inspired.

Introducing Beneufit 
Beneufit is a personalized exercise platform for people with major neurological disorders, tapping into the brain’s natural ability to heal itself. The Beneufit platform is designed to empower

patient health through exercise.


Product Summary
Our patent-pending technology combines exercise, mobile devices, wireless sensors and analytics with the goal of minimizing the condition’s impact on patients, reducing the costs to society and advancing the understanding of exercise’s impact on the brain. The openness and flexibility of the

platform enables researchers to easily test and analyze specific exercise protocols and measure precisely the clinical impact of these protocols.

The Beneufit platform will enable crowdsourced or

community-based scientific discoveries in a low-cost and frictionless manner.

There are three elements that will make this possible.
<li>
Personalize: Any exercise protocol can be loaded into the app. Enables community-based or crowdsourced research.
<li>

Coach: Wireless sensors enable the app to track how closely one complied with the prescribed protocol. Symptom tests track clinical outcomes. Individuals receive higher scores for complying precisely with their scientific protocol.
•  Learn: All regimens on the platform are rated based on their effectiveness at influencing clinical outcomes. The most effective interventions rise to the top.

What You Get

The Coached Workout
An iOS app takes the user’s personalized exercise regimen and coaches each individual through the workout on a second-by-second basis. This gives people a clear understanding of what they should be doing combined with engagement and motivation that pushes people to achieve more than they otherwise could.

iPhone app

Wireless Sensors
Wireless sensors featuring Bluetooth 4.0 technology stream activity data directly to the mobile device. The sensor kit comes complete with a heart rate and cycling cadence sensors. The cycling cadence sensor is designed to work on all stationary, spin and road bikes. The Beneufit system is for stationary use only.



Bluetooth 4.0 Wireless Sensors


Dashboard

The Beneufit dashboard stores workouts and analyzes performance for each session. This information is used to monitor progress over time and understand how closely patients you are following the prescribed exercise regimen.


Dashboard: Workout View

Analytics
A score is generated to simplify the understanding of someone’s compliance with their plan. Their score along with symptom analysis, enables Beneufit to rate effectiveness of each scientific exercise protocol.

Discoveries made through this process will be fed back up to the community for continual refinement. We're hoping this feedback loop becomes a powerful new weapon for researchers across the entire spectrum of health conditions people are faced with.

The People Behind This Project

Our Community Research Project

We seek to prove two important factors in our research project. One is that the Beneufit technology, including personalized and gamified apps can motivate people with Parkinson's disease and other conditions to exercise more than they otherwise would. The other is those who follow the exercise protocol the closest will see the greatest impact on their condition. It's not about how hard or fast you go, it's about how closely you stick to the plan.

We've already tested the system with Parkinson's patients and are highly confident the positive results we've seen can be translated to a large, statistically-significant sample size.

Our story is one of personal empowerment. We're hoping the discoveries made during our project will give people the tools necessary to live the fullest lives possible.

A Healthcare System In Transition
Leveraging exercise to manage chronic disease is exactly what the healthcare system needs. We're transitioning from a procedure-based system where incentives are based on hospital visits to an outcome-based system where the incentive is to keep people out of hospitals.

Prescribing the best exercise regimen for each condition is one of the best strategies for this new paradigm. Until now there has been no way to effectively prescribe exercise regimens, manage  patient compliance, track regimen effectiveness or devise new exercise protocols that maximize beneficial response among patient groups.

Why We Need Your Help
We know the science behind our Parkinson's-fighting cycling protocol works. Our advisor Dr. Jay Alberts of The Cleveland Clinic's groundbreaking study ""It Is Not About the Bike, It Is About the Pedaling: Forced Exercise and Parkinson's Disease"" describes the science. Our advisor Nan Little is living proof of high-cadence cycling's effectiveness.

We believe the best way to positively effect Parkinson's patients condition is to get as many people as possible on the system. By coaching people through their workout, we empower them to fight the disease. By tracking their performance we know how closely they follow the protocol. By mapping protocol compliance to their symptoms, we prove it's effectiveness.

The more people who participate, the more reliable the results. The more reliable the results, the bigger impact on society.

Where Are We In Development
The Bluetooth 4.0 wireless sensors are done. We ordered a small run of 100 sensors for the Early Bird Special and they are leaving Hong Kong for California within the next day or so.

We are testing the iOS app and web dashboard with Parkinson's users and the feedback has been incredible. We will be tweaking things for the next few weeks and will submit the app to the App store in early Dec so we can get the Early Birds on the system as soon as possible.

What We Do With The Funds
The funds form this campaign go directly to ordering more Bluetooth wireless sensors and iterating on our software. Unlike most crowdfunding projects out there, the R&
column2:
D phase is behind us.

We will order more sensors and be hyper-active in supporting the people on our platform to ensure we deliver the best product and experience possible. The feedback and knowledge gleaned from the Early Birds will help refine our software and customer service process as we await delivery of the (with your help) large order we will place upon conclusion of this campaign.

Contribute Now
So please, help us improve lives while proving exercise is medicine for Parkinson's disease.

Thank you,


The Beneufit Team
","Beneufit's Parkinson’s Disease Pilot Study results are in.Beneufit's Parkinson’s Disease Pilot Study demonstrates its product, pdFIT,™ increases manual dexterity and fitness capacity in subjects with Parkinson’s disease.During the 12-week study period subjects increased their fitness capacity as measured by Beneufit’s fitFactor™ score by 38% and manual dexterity as measured by their circleTap™ score by 25%.Click here to access the full report.Exercise As MedicineWe all know exercise is good for you. Anyone who's been diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, had a stroke, heart attack, traumatic brain injury or heart attack knows that exercise is a major part of the healing process. Our StoryThree years ago Beneufit Co-Founder and CEO Jeff Broderick had the pleasure of meeting Nan Little while fly-fishing at Silver Creek, Idaho. Nan was riding her road bike on the deck of the visitors center and she mentioned following a certain protocol had dramatically reduced her Parkinson's disease symptoms. However,Nan was frustrated because there was no way to quantify her performance or track what she was doing over time. Being a technologist and a cyclist himself, Jeff was inspired to take Nan's experience and turn it into a product.In October, three years to the day after their initial encounter Jeff returned to Silver Creek to meet Nan and present her with the product that she inspired. Introducing Beneufit Beneufit is a personalized exercise platform for people with major neurological disorders, tapping into the brain’s natural ability to heal itself. The Beneufit platform is designed to empower

column1: patient health through exercise. Product SummaryOur patent-pending technology combines exercise, mobile devices, wireless sensors and analytics with the goal of minimizing the condition’s impact on patients, reducing the costs to society and advancing the understanding of exercise’s impact on the brain. The openness and flexibility of the
platform enables researchers to easily test and analyze specific exercise protocols and measure precisely the clinical impact of these protocols. The Beneufit platform will enable crowdsourced or
community-based scientific discoveries in a low-cost and frictionless manner.There are three elements that will make this possible.
Personalize: Any exercise protocol can be loaded into the app. Enables community-based or crowdsourced research.

Coach: Wireless sensors enable the app to track how closely one complied with the prescribed protocol. Symptom tests track clinical outcomes. Individuals receive higher scores for complying precisely with their scientific protocol.
Learn: All regimens on the platform are rated based on their effectiveness at influencing clinical outcomes. The most effective interventions rise to the top.

What You GetThe Coached WorkoutAn iOS app takes the user’s personalized exercise regimen and coaches each individual through the workout on a second-by-second basis. This gives people a clear understanding of what they should be doing combined with engagement and motivation that pushes people to achieve more than they otherwise could.iPhone app Wireless SensorsWireless sensors featuring Bluetooth 4.0 technology stream activity data directly to the mobile device. The sensor kit comes complete with a heart rate and cycling cadence sensors. The cycling cadence sensor is designed to work on all stationary, spin and road bikes. The Beneufit system is for stationary use only.Bluetooth 4.0 Wireless SensorsDashboard

The Beneufit dashboard stores workouts and analyzes performance for each session. This information is used to monitor progress over time and understand how closely patients you are following the prescribed exercise regimen.Dashboard: Workout ViewAnalyticsA score is generated to simplify the understanding of someone’s compliance with their plan. Their score along with symptom analysis, enables Beneufit to rate effectiveness of each scientific exercise protocol. Discoveries made through this process will be fed back up to the community for continual refinement. We're hoping this feedback loop becomes a powerful new weapon for researchers across the entire spectrum of health conditions people are faced with.The People Behind This ProjectOur Community Research ProjectWe seek to prove two important factors in our research project. One is that the Beneufit technology, including personalized and gamified apps can motivate people with Parkinson's disease and other conditions to exercise more than they otherwise would. The other is those who follow the exercise protocol the closest will see the greatest impact on their condition. It's not about how hard or fast you go, it's about how closely you stick to the plan. We've already tested the system with Parkinson's patients and are highly confident the positive results we've seen can be translated to a large, statistically-significant sample size. Our story is one of personal empowerment. We're hoping the discoveries made during our project will give people the tools necessary to live the fullest lives possible.A Healthcare System In TransitionLeveraging exercise to manage chronic disease is exactly what the healthcare system needs. We're transitioning from a procedure-based system where incentives are based on hospital visits to an outcome-based system where the incentive is to keep people out of hospitals. Prescribing the best exercise regimen for each condition is one of the best strategies for this new paradigm. Until now there has been no way to effectively prescribe exercise regimens, manage  patient compliance, track regimen effectiveness or devise new exercise protocols that maximize beneficial response among patient groups.Why We Need Your HelpWe know the science behind our Parkinson's-fighting cycling protocol works. Our advisor Dr. Jay Alberts of The Cleveland Clinic's groundbreaking study ""It Is Not About the Bike, It Is About the Pedaling: Forced Exercise and Parkinson's Disease"" describes the science. Our advisor Nan Little is living proof of high-cadence cycling's effectiveness. We believe the best way to positively effect Parkinson's patients condition is to get as many people as possible on the system. By coaching people through their workout, we empower them to fight the disease. By tracking their performance we know how closely they follow the protocol. By mapping protocol compliance to their symptoms, we prove it's effectiveness. The more people who participate, the more reliable the results. The more reliable the results, the bigger impact on society. Where Are We In DevelopmentThe Bluetooth 4.0 wireless sensors are done. We ordered a small run of 100 sensors for the Early Bird Special and they are leaving Hong Kong for California within the next day or so. We are testing the iOS app and web dashboard with Parkinson's users and the feedback has been incredible. We will be tweaking things for the next few weeks and will submit the app to the App store in early Dec so we can get the Early Birds on the system as soon as possible.What We Do With The FundsThe funds form this campaign go directly to ordering more Bluetooth wireless sensors and iterating on our software. Unlike most crowdfunding projects out there, the R&D phase is behind us. We will order more sensors and be hyper-active in supporting the people on our platform to ensure we deliver the best product and experience possible. The feedback and knowledge gleaned from the Early Birds will help refine our software and customer service process as we await delivery of the (with your help) large order we will place upon conclusion of this campaign.Contribute NowSo please, help us improve lives while proving exercise is medicine for Parkinson's disease. Thank you,The Beneufit Team",10.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","San Francisco, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/beneufit-exercise-as-medicine/pica

column2: >I am Preeti Gahlot I come from Rishikesh in Uttrakand, India the birthplace of yoga, I started exploring yoga at the age of 14. I didn't start Yoga to be a teacher, at that time I did not know what yoga was but was an eager study and absorbed much. I feel I am so fortunate to have grown up in the birth place of yoga and am blessed to have received such a gift. Yoga is in my blood. Now with 14 years of practice and 8 years of teaching I offer a method of teaching that combines my varied knowledge and experience and offers all level of yoga practitioner insight and challenge.

column1: <div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div>
<ul>
<li>

Yoga is natural, and is instrumental in creating a healthy body and a healthy mind. Yoga (the word) means union and works on both the mind and the body creating harmony and well being for everyone. But in my opinion Yoga is an experience The Indian yogic tradition consists of so much more than just postures and breathing exercises: philosophy, diet and natural medicine are all part of this rich yogic tradition and my teaching.

I started my yoga practice when I was 14 years old, studying Iyengar yoga with Swami Rudra in Rishikesh. I finished my post graduate in 2005, I hold a masters in Patanjali, Hatha and Astanga yoga. Studies in Ayurveda and yoga therapy as well as a masters in Philosophy from the Garhwal University in Rishikesh.

•  My yoga studio will be a place where people can learn more than stretching and discover the benefits of yoga and find the treasure in themselves. It is very important for me because real yoga is disappearing, yoga is not about keeping up with the instructor, its about learning from them and doing your own practice to discover yourself and your body. Yoga is not a workout it is about working on yourself. I want practitioners to focus on basics and not labels and understand the reality of it and understand the value of it before its gets lost.

• I wish to help people understand the real value of yoga and contributors will help me create a space to reach more people in this mission. It will be a dream come true and offer me much happiness and satisfaction to provide this.
<ul>
• Its not my job its my passion and you can help me to share my passion with others
• Construction, equipment, decoration, utilities etc plus indiagog and paypal fee + $20,000USD
• If I do not reach my goal I will not give up and will continue with my hard work and and I will finish this project.
<ul>
• My project is important and valuable for all because with real yoga we can make our mind and body healthy and if mind and body is healthy life is beautiful. We all deserve it.
• check my basic website-www.askaboutyoga .com
Thank you for your support.
Some people may be unable to contribute, but that doesn't mean they can’t help:
• share it with other, word of mouth is the powerful thing.

Who are we? 

Operation Grow4Vets is a not-for-profit operating out of Colorado. Follow the link below to meet our team!
column3:
>Operation Grow4Vets Team Page

What do we do?

We offer free cannabis and cannabis infused products to disabled veterans. Unfortunately the Veteran's Administration system would rather provide them with Deadly Drug Cocktails than with a non-lethal alternative that has been proven time and again to be affective against PTSD, TBI, Chronic Pain, and many other conditions that our country's heroes suffer from. 

Why?

A veteran takes their own life every 65 minutes. Most by prescription drug overdose. Operation Grow4Vets seeks to spread a life-saving alternative to those who deserve it most- Cannabis.

column1: <div class=""span8 product_description"">
Medicating Colorado Vets Won’t Lose Healthcare
Military vets using medical marijuana will not be disqualified from VA benefits and services according to a local Colorado Veterans Administration medical center.

“Use of state-approved marijuana does not disqualify a veteran for healthcare, and it will not result in any sort of retaliation or denial of services,” VA Eastern Colorado Healthcare System spokesman Dan Warvi told FOX31 Denver.
Read More
<div class=""span8 product_description"">
Operation Grow4Vets: Helping Veterans Gain Access To Cannabis Medicine
As we’ve discussed before, cannabis has shown promise in the treatment of PTSD. Despite this, it is not considered to be a qualifying condition for medical marijuana in the state of Colorado.

Thanks to the passing of Amendment 64 and the opening of retail cannabis facilities in Colorado earlier this year, veterans have been able to secure access to cannabis in a safe, regulated environment.
Read More

column2: >

column1: <div class=""span8 product_description"">
Colorado Group To Provide Free Medical Marijuana To Veterans

A new group in Colorado plans on providing cannabis to U.S. military vets as an alternative to using narcotics to treat physical or mental illness sustained during military service. The cost to vets? Nothing.
Called Operation Grow4Vets, the group intends to give away free marijuana, cannabis-infused oils and tinctures, as well as marijuana plant growing equipment, to qualified veterans.
Read More

WOODLAND PARK, Colo. — Operation Grow4Vets has launched the program Project Better Medicine, which will provide free marijuana, edibles and homegrown equipment to veterans in hopes of reducing drug overdose and suicide deaths.
All veterans living in Colorado and under treatment at a VA facility are eligible to enroll.

column36: >A YouTube video from Lee Memorial Health System- Cardiology: Do You Know The Warning Signs of Heart Disease?

column7:
>

Your questions?

Do I need to wait until a heart attack hits me with symptoms?

How do I know that my chest pain will not lead to a heart attack?

column1: Can I have a heart attack detection test that can be done routinely

without worrying about the cost?

Can I just walk into my doctor's office and do a test for identifying early signs of a heart attack?

How could I know that a second heart attack will hit me again?

Can I have a test for assessing the risk of a heart attack prior to a non-heart related major surgery?

Develop a fast and simple blood test for the early detection of a heart attack that can be performed at individual physician clinics, by home based nurse practitioners, by long-term care facility nurses, by nurses at senior centers, by emergency paramedics, etc.  The test format will be similar to the pregnancy detection kit that
is being widely used.  In a pregnancy
detection kit urine sample is used with specific reagents that detect a
pregnancy specific protein whereas
column2: in our proposed kit, few drops of blood

column1: sample will be used along with specific reagents for the detection of cardiac
ischemia and heart attack. Our proposed test kit will be easily accessible and can
be routinely performed outside of hospital laboratories.  It will significantly reduce
healthcare costs and save millions of lives.
A Point-of-Care Test (POCT) for the detection of

cardiac ischemia is not available.  Cardiac ischemia is resulted from blockage in coronary arteries (called atherosclerosis) that causes lack of oxygen and blood to the heart. Cardiac ischemia  is an early indicator of heart attack.  Chest pain is an early symptom of cardiac ischemia.  Some patients may survive their chest pains spontaneously, but, they are at high risk for short term heart attack (Medical Laboratory Observer).  These chest pains may also include inconsistent chest pain that comes and goes, which may be difficult to pinpoint since the pain may appear one day in neck, next day in your shoulder, left hand and jaw and none in next day.   Cardiac ischemia can also occur without any symptoms, a phenomenon called
silent ischemia, which is common in diabetic patients.  ECG is the primary method of diagnosis, but, it has several limitations
in detecting cardiac ischemia (a)  such ECG has only 60 % accuracy in detecting
cardiac ischemia(b) ,   ECG may be abnormal or non-specific in

certain patients with cardiac ischemia or heart attack (c)  and in some cases ECG may be normal. 

Most of the currently available tests for the detection of heart attack are based on troponin detection.  However, troponin test may not be the best suitable test for the early detection of heart attack because increased levels of troponin in blood can be detected only after the heart muscles are damaged due to a heart attack. Very high levels of troponin in blood indicate that a heart attack has occurred.  It may take approximately 6 hours to detect increased levels of troponin in patients who have had a heart attack.  Therefore, our goal will be to detect early signs of heart attack before the occurrence of heart damage or a heart attack. 

With the combination of cardiac ischemia detection and other blood markers of heart attack detection, our technology will have direct application in detecting cardiac ischemia and heart attack in three different medical situations:

(1) The classical case where the individual presents with chest pain/angina.

(2) The individual has no observable symptoms traditionally associated with heart attack, but has recently had a silent cardiac ischemia and heart attack, which is not diagnosed with current methods. 

(3) The individual has not had a heart attack, but has a personal history of heart attack, or a family history of heart attack, and conservative, prudent medical care would suggest a cardiac catheterization be performed, unnecessarily.


What are the

benefits of early detection of heart attack? 

“In a heart attack, every minute that passes

causes more of the heart muscle to die”- Circulation.

“About
47% of sudden cardiac deaths occur outside a hospital. This suggests that

many people with heart disease don't act on early warning signs”-Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

“To receive the best care, you have about 90 minutes from the onset of the heart attack for an interventional cardiologist or surgeon to restore the flow of blood to the heart before critical heart tissue dies or is damaged”- The Society for Cardiovascular Angiography and Interventions (SCAI).

""Half of deaths due to a heart attack occur in the first 3 or 4 hours after symptoms begin. The sooner treatment begins, the better the chances of survival""- Merck Manual. 

“Chances of surviving a heart attack can improve when an individual recognizes the symptoms early and seeks immediate medical attention”-Cedars-Sinai.

""The beneficial effect of fibrinolytic therapy is substantially higher in patients presenting within 2 h after symptom onset compared to those presenting later""(Golden hour) - The Lancet.

“All regular cardiovascular screening tests
should begin at age 20. The frequency of follow up will depend on your level of
risk”–
American Heart Association.
“Eighty-five
percent of heart damage occurs within the first two hours of a heart attack, so
early detection and treatment is the key to saving lives”- Johnston Health.
“Routine lipid testing can miss up to 75% these people. Panels of blood tests that look beyond cholesterol and triglycerides can catch 90% or more of people headed for cardiovascular disease”
column16:
>.

“Heart disease early detection can save the U.S. healthcare system tremendous amounts. Hundreds of billions of dollars can be saved, both direct and indirectly. Reducing the cost and resource burden on the system can help Medicare/Medicaid solvency, reduce our national debt, or enable a focus on other diseases”- Heartsavers Clinic.

“The

column1: sudden, unexpected loss of a friend or loved one can be one of the most
difficult things to cope with. While most losses are devastating, a sudden loss
can leave us feeling uncertain, anxious, and vulnerable about life and the

future”-Joleen Watson.


Key features of our proposed test for the early detection of heart attack  

(Patent pending technology)

•  Three separate tests in a single test strip

•  Detection of early signs of heart attack and progression of heart attack

•  Results within 15 minutes

•  Test can be performed outside of hospital laboratories

•  Testing can be routinely performed

•  Easily accessible to anyone

•  Cost-effective


Three different tests can be done in a single test strip using our proposed early heart attack detection test
We will develop a single test that
can identify early symptoms of heart attack, chances of having a heart attack
down the road, progression towards heart attack and occurrence of a heart
attack.  These tests are approved by US FDA or similar agencies worldwide
and are being currently used in hospital laboratories for the diagnosis of heart
attack.  However, these tests are done separately and it takes
longer time.  A single rapid test for simultaneous detection of cardiac
ischemia, progression of heart attack and occurrence of heart attack is not
currently available.  Though the US FDA approved cardiac ischemia test was
discovered almost 24 years back, but till now a strip format fast detection test
for cardiac ischemia is not available.  We will make it possible through
our patent pending invention.
column4:
> 


Early indicator molecules of heart attack that appear in blood at different stages of heart attack will be tested simultaneously 

We have developed a technology

column1: that can be used for the detection of reversible cardiac ischemia indicator
molecules in blood (patent pending). This can be used for the detection of
early signs of heart attack.  We will develop a single test to identify
indicator molecules of cardiac ischemia, transition towards heart attack and
occurrence of a heart attack present in blood samples.
column5: >Following is an animated video showing our proposed Point-of-Care Test (POCT) for the early detection of cardiac ischemia and heart attack.
column18:
schema=youtube"" width=""580"">


Surprising stories and facts about heart attacks

""Young women fare worse than young men after heart attack""- American Heart Association Meeting Report Abstract June 2014.

“I finally went to the ER and recited my symptoms to the nurse. The

column1: doctor who examined me wanted to give me some Motrin and send me home, never
ordering any tests. I knew something was terribly wrong with me and demanded to
be given some kind of test. I looked above me and saw an EKG and asked to have
one”- Having a Heart Attack at 30.
column3: _r=0"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Helvetica, sans-serif
column5: target=""_blank"">Too Young to Have a Heart Attack

column1:
Story of Diane Harrington where her EKG looked normal. 

“The lesson is that just because someone is not “old” that does not mean that symptoms such as chest pain and shortness of breath are not signs of a heart attack”- Can young people have heart attacks?
ambulance arrived, and the crew checked me over. They managed to calm me down a
little and took an ECG (a measurement of the heartbeat). They said there was a
slight abnormality, but because of my young age (36) and the fact that I led a
healthy lifestyle and there was no family history of heart problems, they were
happy to rule out anything serious there and then. Even so, we decided I should
go to hospital immediately to get properly checked out. After a few hours, I
was let home – with some indigestion medicine”<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column7: >My heart attack at 36

column1: Men’s Health Watch reminds men that they should not ignore heart attack warning
symptoms just because they are “too young” to have heart disease, and that
prevention should start early”-<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column7: >Why do some young men have heart attacks?

column1: too young for a heart attack, you need to confront the scary truth: Every year
about 40,000 American women under age 55 are hospitalized for heart disease,
and 16,000 of them die. What's more, younger women's heart attacks are fatal
twice as often as men's. In fact, women who are 35 to 44 are the only Americans
whose coronary heart disease mortality is rising (by 1.3 percent a year),
according to a new study in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology”.
goes up in men older than 45 and women older than 55, but it can happen even
earlier”- Heart attacks can happen at any age.
“Women age 55 or younger may
fare worse than their male counterparts after having a heart attack”- Young women fare worse than young men after heart attack.
the 34-year-old who had the massive heart attack?"" I had emergency
surgery. But the damage was done
column2: only part of my heart muscle functions. I had

column1: to quit a job I loved, and my life is completely changed. They thought I was
too young to have a heart attack”- <span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column4: >Angela's story

column1: “Chest pain was the most
common symptom of heart attack in both sexes, researchers found that one in
five women age 55 and younger didn't experience chest pain with their heart
attack. Plus, women in general were less likely to experience chest pain from
heart attack than men”- Heart Attacks In Young Women Don't Always Cause Chest Pain.

column4: >Heart disease on the rise in young people.

column1: didn't think they were at risk for heart disease. Their stories are proof that
you could be in danger without knowing it”- <span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column4: >The Surprising Faces Of Heart Attack.
column7:
>

 

Your contributions and perks 

Our goal is not only just about our passion for developing a cost-effective innovative technology that can save

column1:
thousands of lives but also we are committed to share our profits and pledged to donate to non-profit organizations who directly support heart disease related research matching your contributions (Details are provided in Section C  in the next section- ""Detailed description of our campaign"").  It should be pointed out that the final product needs the approval of US FDA and regulatory bodies in other countries. Therefore, the goal of this project is to develop a prototype that leads to development of a final product that may satisfy all of the guidelines proposed by the world's leading cardiac organizations and meet all the requirements of regulatory bodies.  Your contributions will be used for developing a clinically viable prototype for the early detection of a heart attack and this technology development process requires large amounts of capital.


Who we are?
We are a small group of motivated scientists who are passionate about science with strong scientific
background (please refer to Section D in the next section to learn more about us).   We are focused on developing innovative diagnostic tests than can
save millions of lives worldwide.  The passion and inspiration for
developing a test for the early detection of heart attack was resulted from one
of our own scientist’s personal decade-long journey of searching for a scientific solution after the sudden

loss of his loved one and several other personal life experiences.  Pointcare Genomics Corp. is a start-up diagnostics company <a href=""https://www.wdfi.org/apps/CorpSearch/Details.aspx?entityID=P063565&amp
column12:
orgTypes="" rel=""noopener nofollow"" target=""_blank"">incorporated in the State of Wisconsin (founded in May 2014).  Our website is yet to come.  


Please support us to save millions of lives worldwide.  Your

column1: support will help us to develop a cost-effective innovative technology that can
prevent sudden, unexpected  loss of a loved

one or a friend.

column1: Rationale behind our technology:   There are specific markers which appear in blood when

Amount requested:  US$250,000.00

The funds raised through this campaign will be used for developing a POCT prototype and will be used only for the technology development, primarily for the optimization of reagents and detection conditions, not for any kind of research on finding new markers for the early detection of cardiac ischemia or heart attack.  It should be pointed out that the final product needs the approval of US FDA and regulatory bodies in other countries.  Therefore, the goal of this project is to develop a prototype that leads to development of a final product that may satisfy all of the guidelines proposed by the world's leading cardiac organizations and meet all the requirements of regulatory bodies.

Purpose of the amount requested:  Laboratory reagents and other consumables, consultant fees, capital instruments, point-of-care device components and salaries.

Achievable goal:  This funding will be used to develop our core invention, a prototype of non-clinical Point-of-Care Test (POCT) device for the detection of ischemia.  The reagents and materials used for developing this prototype will not be clinical grade reagents.  To reduce costs, commercially available research-grade reagents (as opposed to costly clinical-grade reagents) will be used.

PROPERTY ON THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY
Patent pending
THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY
According to a new report from BCC Research, the
global market for in vitro diagnostic tests for cardiac biomarkers is expected
to grow to $7.2 billion by 2018 with a five-year compound annual growth rate
(CAGR) of 12.8% 15.   Of this 7.2 billion, $3.1 billion is in the US with a CAGR of 9.6%.   Point-of-Care testing has been identified as the growing
market for cardiac markers. Troponin is the
leading marker used in the detection of heart attacks or myocardial infarctions
(MI).  The worldwide market for cardiac troponin testing is estimated to be
$1.2 billion (with 12% annual growth rate).   Point-of-Care market for
troponin tests carried out in the emergency room (ER) is approximately $350 M
and the rest is for laboratory-based testing 16.  The potential market
size of our technology, with a combination of two or more tests in a single
platform, would likely be higher than the current market for testing just
troponin alone.
","A YouTube video from Lee Memorial Health System- Cardiology: Do You Know The Warning Signs of Heart Disease?
Your questions?Do I need to wait until a heart attack hits me with symptoms?How do I know that my chest pain will not lead to a heart attack?
Can I have a heart attack detection test that can be done routinely
without worrying about the cost?Can I just walk into my doctor's office and do a test for identifying early signs of a heart attack?
How could I know that a second heart attack will hit me again?Can I have a test for assessing the risk of a heart attack prior to a non-heart related major surgery?
Our solution

Develop a fast and simple blood test for the early detection of a heart attack that can be performed at individual physician clinics, by home based nurse practitioners, by long-term care facility nurses, by nurses at senior centers, by emergency paramedics, etc.  The test format will be similar to the pregnancy detection kit that
is being widely used.  In a pregnancy
detection kit urine sample is used with specific reagents that detect a
pregnancy specific protein whereas
column2: in our proposed kit, few drops of blood

column1: sample will be used along with specific reagents for the detection of cardiac
ischemia and heart attack. Our proposed test kit will be easily accessible and can
be routinely performed outside of hospital laboratories.  It will significantly reduce
healthcare costs and save millions of lives.Our unique technology
A Point-of-Care Test (POCT) for the detection of

cardiac ischemia is not available.  Cardiac ischemia is resulted from blockage in coronary arteries (called atherosclerosis) that causes lack of oxygen and blood to the heart. Cardiac ischemia  is an early indicator of heart attack.  Chest pain is an early symptom of cardiac ischemia.  Some patients may survive their chest pains spontaneously, but, they are at high risk for short term heart attack (Medical Laboratory Observer).  These chest pains may also include inconsistent chest pain that comes and goes, which may be difficult to pinpoint since the pain may appear one day in neck, next day in your shoulder, left hand and jaw and none in next day.   Cardiac ischemia can also occur without any symptoms, a phenomenon called
silent ischemia, which is common in diabetic patients.  ECG is the primary method of diagnosis, but, it has several limitations
in detecting cardiac ischemia (a)  such ECG has only 60 % accuracy in detecting
cardiac ischemia(b) ,   ECG may be abnormal or non-specific in

certain patients with cardiac ischemia or heart attack (c)  and in some cases ECG may be normal. Most of the currently available tests for the detection of heart attack are based on troponin detection.  However, troponin test may not be the best suitable test for the early detection of heart attack because increased levels of troponin in blood can be detected only after the heart muscles are damaged due to a heart attack. Very high levels of troponin in blood indicate that a heart attack has occurred.  It may take approximately 6 hours to detect increased levels of troponin in patients who have had a heart attack.  Therefore, our goal will be to detect early signs of heart attack before the occurrence of heart damage or a heart attack. With the combination of cardiac ischemia detection and other blood markers of heart attack detection, our technology will have direct application in detecting cardiac ischemia and heart attack in three different medical situations:(1) The classical case where the individual presents with chest pain/angina.(2) The individual has no observable symptoms traditionally associated with heart attack, but has recently had a silent cardiac ischemia and heart attack, which is not diagnosed with current methods. (3) The individual has not had a heart attack, but has a personal history of heart attack, or a family history of heart attack, and conservative, prudent medical care would suggest a cardiac catheterization be performed, unnecessarily.What are the
benefits of early detection of heart attack? “In a heart attack, every minute that passes
causes more of the heart muscle to die”- Circulation.“About
47% of sudden cardiac deaths occur outside a hospital. This suggests that

many people with heart disease don't act on early warning signs”-Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).“To receive the best care, you have about 90 minutes from the onset of the heart attack for an interventional cardiologist or surgeon to restore the flow of blood to the heart before critical heart tissue dies or is damaged”- The Society for Cardiovascular Angiography and Interventions (SCAI).""Half of deaths due to a heart attack occur in the first 3 or 4 hours after symptoms begin. The sooner treatment begins, the better the chances of survival""- Merck Manual. “Chances of surviving a heart attack can improve when an individual recognizes the symptoms early and seeks immediate medical attention”-Cedars-Sinai.

The beneficial effect of fibrinolytic therapy is substantially higher in patients presenting within 2 h after symptom onset compared to those presenting later""(Golden hour) - The Lancet.“All regular cardiovascular screening tests
should begin at age 20. The frequency of follow up will depend on your level of
risk”–
American Heart Association.
“Eighty-five
percent of heart damage occurs within the first two hours of a heart attack, so
early detection and treatment is the key to saving lives”- Johnston Health.

“Routine lipid testing can miss up to 75% these people. Panels of blood tests that look beyond cholesterol and triglycerides can catch 90% or more of people headed for cardiovascular disease”- Naturalchoice.“Heart disease early detection can save the U.S. healthcare system tremendous amounts. Hundreds of billions of dollars can be saved, both direct and indirectly. Reducing the cost and resource burden on the system can help Medicare/Medicaid solvency, reduce our national debt, or enable a focus on other diseases”- Heartsavers Clinic.“The
sudden, unexpected loss of a friend or loved one can be one of the most
difficult things to cope with. While most losses are devastating, a sudden loss
can leave us feeling uncertain, anxious, and vulnerable about life and the

future”-Joleen Watson.Key features of our proposed test for the early detection of heart attack  (Patent pending technology)•  Three separate tests in a single test strip•  Detection of early signs of heart attack and progression of heart attack•  Results within 15 minutes•  Test can be performed outside of hospital laboratories•  Testing can be routinely performed•  Easily accessible to anyone•  Cost-effectiveThree different tests can be done in a single test strip using our proposed early heart attack detection test
We will develop a single test that
can identify early symptoms of heart attack, chances of having a heart attack
down the road, progression towards heart attack and occurrence of a heart
attack.  These tests are approved by US FDA or similar agencies worldwide
and are being currently used in hospital laboratories for the diagnosis of heart
attack.  However, these tests are done separately and it takes
longer time.  A single rapid test for simultaneous detection of cardiac
ischemia, progression of heart attack and occurrence of heart attack is not
currently available.  Though the US FDA approved cardiac ischemia test was
discovered almost 24 years back, but till now a strip format fast detection test
for cardiac ischemia is not available.  We will make it possible through
our patent pending invention. Early indicator molecules of heart attack that appear in blood at different stages of heart attack will be tested simultaneously We have developed a technology
that can be used for the detection of reversible cardiac ischemia indicator
molecules in blood (patent pending). This can be used for the detection of
early signs of heart attack.  We will develop a single test to identify
indicator molecules of cardiac ischemia, transition towards heart attack and

occurrence of a heart attack present in blood samples.Following is an animated video showing our proposed Point-of-Care Test (POCT) for the early detection of cardiac ischemia and heart attack.Surprising stories and facts about heart attacks""Young women fare worse than young men after heart attack""- American Heart Association Meeting Report Abstract June 2014.“I finally went to the ER and recited my symptoms to the nurse. PROPERTY ON THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY
Patent pending2.   BUSINESS PERSPECTIVES OF
THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY
According to a new report from BCC Research, the
global market for in vitro diagnostic tests for cardiac biomarkers is expected
to grow to $7.2 billion by 2018 with a five-year compound annual growth rate
(CAGR) of 12.8% 15.   Of this 7.2 billion, $3.1 billion is in the US with a CAGR of 9.6%.   Point-of-Care testing has been identified as the growing
market for cardiac markers. Troponin is the
leading marker used in the detection of heart attacks or myocardial infarctions
(MI).  The worldwide market for cardiac troponin testing is estimated to be
$1.2 billion (with 12% annual growth rate).   Point-of-Care market for
troponin tests carried out in the emergency room (ER) is approximately $350 M
and the rest is for laboratory-based testing 16.  The potential market
size of our technology, with a combination of two or more tests in a single
platform, would likely be higher than the current market for testing just
troponin alone.",18.0,2,"1 Campaign

 We are AYSO Region 4 and we serve four communities in Southern California - Westlake Village, Agoura Hills, Oak Park, and Calabasas. AYSO National office has designated us a Platinum Region, their highest recognition. Over 2,000 families depend on us each year to provide a fun, safe experience for their children. Help us contribute to building three new soccer fields.

Since we are spread out over ten miles, we need to utilize space at twelve different locations (including school playgrounds and parks.) The cost of using these fields is, by far, our greatest expense.

We now have an opportunity to participate in the construction of new soccer fields as part of a joint project by the city of Westlake Village and YMCA. In order for our Region to secure use of these beautiful new fields, we are conducting this fundraiser in an effort to supplement our current Non-Profit operations.

Grading is complete, and construction has already begun on the baseball fields.

 

Artist’s conception of finished soccer fields (for use Fall 2015)

 

PROJECT DESCRIPTION

The Westlake Village/YMCA project consists of a multi-purpose recreational park and sports complex, with a YMCA facility. The project highlights include:
<li>

YMCA facility - a two-story, 48,000 sq. ft. structure will include a family fitness center, gymnasium, indoor 25-meter swimming pool with 8 lanes, rock climbing wall, multipurpose room, and a 4600 sq. ft. Dole facility, with an interactive WiFi Learning Center, café, exhibit space, and store.
<li>

Baseball complex - includes three baseball/softball fields for kids 10-12 years old. The fields will use synthetic turf, and will include dug-outs, bullpens, batting cages, and bleachers for each field
<li>

Soccer complex - includes three fields for use by Under 12 players. The fields will be fully lighted for much needed evening play and practices, and will have a concession stand, restrooms, picnic area, and a gazebo nearby.
• Recreational facilities and park amenities
<li>
Skateboard park
<li>
Instructional/multi-sport court
<li>
Picnic area and tot lot
<li>
Concession and restroom facilities
<li>
Gazebo area
<li>
Circumferential path with par course - a walking, running path that encircles the entire complex, including exercise stations along the route.
